description: Classification of books published by the 18th-century publishing house, the Société typographique de Neuchâtel

Abbey of Saint-Claude.definition: Works concerning this abbey, one of the last in France to possess serfs. A sub-category of the keywords: ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ + ‘Catholicism’ + ‘Religious houses’ + ‘France’.

Abelard, Pierre.definition: Medieval cleric, philosopher and tutor known for his passionate affair with his charge, Héloise, and subsequent emasculation.

Abstemiousness.definition: Non-fiction works concerned with abstinence or moderation towards pleasures of the flesh, whether alcohol, sex or food.

Accounting.definition: Works relating to the practice of keeping accounts.

Acoustics.definition: Works dealing with the physics of sound. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Science’ + 'Physics'.

Acting.definition: Works relating to the art of acting.

Actors and Actresses.definition: Works relating to the public and private lives of actors and actresses and other persons involved in theatre.

Aesthetics.definition: Works relating to the appreciation or philosophy of art and beauty.

Afterlife.definition: Works focussing strongly on the afterlife and places associated with the afterlife (Heaven, Hell, Hades etc.). Works depicting imagined conversations with the dead are covered under the keyword ‘Dialogues of the Dead’ and generally not found under this keyword.

Agriculture.definition: Works relating to agriculture and farming, both arable or animal husbandry.

Agronomy.definition: Works relating to the business or ‘economics’ of ‘agriculture’.

Alchemy.definition: Works relating to the study or practice of alchemy or to alchemists. Precise content will determine whether this is also science, pseudo-science. A biography of a charlatan such as Cagliostro would not normally be considered ‘science, or ‘pseudo-science’ as its focus is not on the study of alchemy.

Allegorical Works.definition: Fictional works identified as having a hidden, deeper moral meaning than is immediately apparent. Typically allegorical works in the database are fables or tales of real or imaginary foreign lands.

Alps.definition: Works relating the mountains known as the Alps or Alpine region. Thus, uniquely, this keyword serves both as a regional tag and stand alone term.

American Revolution.definition: Works relating to the American Revolution (American War of Independence) and the international conflict (the American Revolutionary War) that it unleashed.

Amorous adventures.definition: Works relating multiple sexual amours of one or more characters – these may be fictional, loosely based on fact or autobiographical, thus extending from Faublas to Anecdotes du Madame Du Barry, Casanova’s memoirs or the Portefeuille de Mme Gourdan. The relating of such tales may or may not be erotic or pornographic in nature. Fictional works in this category would usually be described as ‘aventures’ or ‘intrigues’ ‘galants’ in Martin et al. Bibliographie du genre Romanesque francais.

Amorous Correspondence.definition: Works primarily containing love letters between lovers. A sub-category of ‘Lives and Letters’ and ‘Correspondence’.

Anatomy.definition: Works relating to human anatomy. NB. Works relating to animal anatomy are categorised under ‘biology’, ‘zoology’ and / or ‘veterinary science’.

Ancient world.definition: Works relating to the ancient, pre-classical, world, including preclassical Biblical history.

Anecdotes.definition: Collections of miscellaneous anecdotes (ie about various persons etc). Intended to be used where the anecdotes are miscellaneous in subject matter. Cf. ‘Scandalous Anecdotes’ or ‘Biographical Anecdotes’

Animal husbandry.definition: Works relating to the farming and care of farm / working animals. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Agriculture’.

Anne of Austria.definition: French Queen, wife of Louis XIII; mother of Louis XIV, serving as his regent 1643-51, with Mazarin (qv.) as her chief minister.

Anthropology.definition: Works relating to the academic study of human beings, particularly indigenous non-Eurasian peoples. NB. The scientific discipline Anthropology did not exist at the time covered by this database.

Anti-Aristocratic Works.definition: Works in which a primary theme is the expression persistent and strong hostility to the aristocracy, in theory of practice, whether by polemic or satirical means.

Anti-Clerical Works.definition: Works attacking or satirising members of clergy in general, usually using stock stereo-types. NB. ‘Anti-clerical works’ are not necessarily about, and so do not always carry the keyword, ‘Religion’.

Aphrodisiacs.definition: Works relating to foods, drinks, perfumes and other materials supposed to inspire or provoke sexual lust.

Apologetic works.definition: Works in defence of Christian religion or Christian denominations against religious scepticism. QV. Sceptical works. All ‘Apologetic works’ are by definition ‘Works of Religiosity’, but not all carry the keywords ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ (eg. works focused on scientific ideas).

Arable farming.definition: Works devoted to crops needing ploughing / annual planting. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Agriculture’.

Arboriculture.definition: Works relating to the cultivation of trees. A sub-category of Agriculture.

Architecture.definition: Works relating to the design or study of buildings or classical monuments.

Aromatherapy.definition: Works relating to the medicinal or beneficial effects of scents. Cf. ‘Perfumes’.

Art Criticism.definition: Works critiquing works of art. A sub-category of Fine Art.

Art History.definition: Works relating to the History of Art. Generally a sub-category of ‘Fine Arts’.

Artillery.definition: Works relating to the making, deployment or use of cannons and other heavy ordnance. A sub-category of ‘Military Science’ and ‘Military Affairs’.

Assembly of Notables.definition: Works relating to one or both of political bodies known as Assemblies of Notables summoned in 1787 and 1788 in an attempt to resolve France’s pre-revolutionary financial and political crisis. A sub-category of ‘Politics’ + ‘Parliamentary bodies’ + ‘France’.

Assyria.definition: Can refer to both the region and the empire of Assyria.

Astrology.definition: Works relating to the pseudo-science of astrology.

Astronomy.definition: Works relating to the systematic, scientific study of the heavens [as opposed to ‘Astrology’]. Generally works with these keywords also carry the keyword ‘Science’, but this is not always the case: e.g. when dealing with astronomy as part of history of ancient world and its chronology.

Atheism.definition: Works exploring, treating or expounding Atheism. Does not imply ideological sympathies, cf. ‘atheist work’; ‘sceptical works’; ‘apologetic works’.  A sub-category of ‘Religion’.

Atheist work.definition: Works supporting and expounding atheist doctrines, or widely conceived by contemporaries to support and expound them.

Austrian Empire.definition: Can refer according to context to both to the imperial heartlands (Hungary and the Hereditary Lands) and to the entire empire, including Italian and Belgian possessions.

Austro-Turkish Wars.definition: Works relating to the wars between the Austrian and Ottoman empires.

Autobiography.definition: Works of biography written, or suspected to be written by their subject. Will carry the term ‘Spurious work’ if it is known not in fact to be by the subject. May be by an amanuensis. A sub-category of ‘Lives and letters’ + ‘biography’.

Aviary Birds.definition: Works discussing bird species commonly kept in aviaries, whether from a scientific, practical or artistic point of view. A sub-category of ‘Ornithology’.

Aviation.definition: Any work concerned with human (attempts at) flight, whether through mechanical means, balloons or other methods.

Babylon.definition: Can refer to both the city and empire of Babylon.

Baking.definition: Works relating to the baking of bread and cakes. A sub-category of ‘Household Skills’ + ‘Cookery’.

Ballet.definition: Dramatic works or musical scores identified as incorporating or accompanying ballet style dancing. Like other dramatic terms in the database, these terms tend to be drawn from the works themselves, either directly from titles or title-pages, or indirectly through the César database. A sub-category of ‘Dancing’ and ‘Music’.

Ballooning.definition: Works relating to the art, science or experience of flying in hot air balloons. A sub-category of ‘Aviation’.

Baltic region.definition: This region is understood to cover the states of Russia, Poland, Sweden, Prussia, Denmark, [plus Courland, Finland, Norway, Lithuania]

Banking.definition: Works relating to the business and practice of banking.

Bastille.definition: Works relating to the Bastille fortress and prison in Paris.

Bayle, Pierre.definition: French protestant exile, writer and philopopher (1647-1706)

Beaumarchais.definition: French playwright, secret agent and adventurer.

Beaumont, Christophe de.definition: Controversial archbishop of Paris and scourge of the Jansenists, notorious for his role in the refusal of the sacraments scandal.

Beauty.definition: Works treating, describing or analysing beauty.

Beekeeping.definition: Works relating to Apiculture and the care and encouragement of bees. A sub-category of ‘Agriculture’.

Belgium.definition: According to context, this keyword can refer to the entire area covered by modern Belgium (including the areas ruled by the Prince bishop of Liège and Luxembourg), or the part of it under Austrian rule and generally known as the Austrian Netherlands.

Berne.definition: Can refer to either the town of Berne or its wider Canton and Bernese Empire.

Berwick, Marechal duc de.definition: French general, lived 1660-1734; natural son of James II of England.

Bible stories.definition: Narrative versions of stories taken from the Bible. A sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’.

Biblical history.definition: Works dedicated to the history of Biblical peoples, primarily old testament, and treating the Bible as a major source. Usually also associated with some / all of the following keywords: ‘Religion’; ‘Ancient world’; ‘Biblical study’. NB. In cases where the work’s main focus is not history, this keyword may not necessarily carry keyword ‘History’.

Biblical study.definition: Works which study Biblical texts from a primarily historical or literary standpoint, rather than to discover theological truths. The purpose of such study may be religious or anti-religious.

Bibliography.definition: Works offering systematic catalogues of literary materials or concerned with the preparation or study of lists of literary materials.

Bilingual editions.definition: Texts containing versions of the same work in two different languages within the same book. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Languages’.

Biographical anecdotes.definition: Collection of anecdotes concerning a single (or occasionally related group) of subjects. NB Does not include anecdotes on miscellaneous subjects, for which keyword ‘Anecdotes’ is used. A sub-category of ‘Lives and Letters’.

Biography.definition: Non-fiction works devoted to recounting the life histories of one or more individuals. ‘Biography’ is a sub-category of ‘Lives and Letters’.

Biology.definition: Scientific works concerning biology, the study of living things. Sub-categories include ‘zoology’, ‘entomology’, ‘botany’, ‘micro-biology’ and ‘paleontology’, all of which have their own keywords. The keyword ‘biology’ without any of these sub-disciplines implies a general work covering all or most of these sub-disciplines (micro-biology is the likely exception). See also ‘Natural History (general)’. ‘Biology’ is a sub-category of ‘Science’.

Blanchard, Jean-Pierre.definition: Aviation pioneer who took part in some of the earliest hot air balloon flights (lived 1753-1809).

Boleyn, Anne.definition: Second wife of Henry VIII of England, mother to Elizabeth I. Beheaded in 1536.

Book of secrets.definition: Works containing a miscellaneous mixture of secret recipes, methods and (traditionally) magic spells for use in household tasks and to overcome difficulties and challenges in everyday life. Texts for many of these works date back to medieval times, but less mystical editions, stripped of their magical content, began to appear in the eighteenth century.

Book Trade.definition: Works relating to the book trade. A sub-category of ‘Economics’ + ‘Commerce’.

Book-binding.definition: Works relating to the art of book binding. A sub-category of ‘Manufacturing’ + ‘Industry’ + ‘Trades’.

Borelly, Alexis.definition: Professor of eloquence at the Academy of Gentlemen in Berlin (1738-1815). Also known as Jean-Alexis Borelly.

Bossuet.definition: French bishop, theologian and court preacher to Louis XIV (1637-1704), known for his advocacy of monarchic absolutism and divine right theory.

Botany.definition: Scientific works concerning the study of plants. See also the keyword definitions ‘Biology’, ‘Natural History (general)’. ‘Botany’ is a sub-category of ‘Science’ + ‘Biology’.

Bowdlerised works.definition: Works deliberately stripped of sexually or religiously offensive materials by their editors / publishers and released in sanitised form. As ‘bowdlerisation’ operates at edition level, and categorisation at superbook, bowdlerised works have only been identified where their superbook titles set them apart as separate works, and only bowdlerised editions were traded. NB. the use of this keyword is indicative only – no systematic attempt has been made to identify every work that might be so categorised.

Bread mould.definition: Works relating to bread mould (and means of preserving bread against the same).

Breast-feeding.definition: Works treating the practice of breastfeeding. ‘Breast-feeding’ is a sub-category of ‘Nutrition’ + ‘Child-rearing’.

Bridge-building.definition: Works relating to the construction of bridges. A sub-category of ‘Architecture’ and ‘Engineering’.

Britain.definition: The keyword ‘Britain’ is used in conjunction with the keywords ‘England’, ‘Scotland’ and ‘Ireland’ when one of them appears separately, or on its own to indicate works referring to Britain more generally. This has been done in part to reflect the ambiguity in the French usage of the word ‘Angleterre’ at the period covered by this database.

Buddhism.definition: Works relating to the beliefs and / or practices of the Buddhist religion and its followers. The use of this keyword does not necessarily imply ideological or spiritual sympathy with Buddhism. A sub-category of ‘Religion’.

Building.definition: Works relating to the construction of buildings and / or the skills and materials involved in their construction.

Building materials.definition: Works relating to materials for the construction of buildings and their use. A sub-category of ‘Building’

Burlesque.definition: Denotes plays described as ‘parades’ in the Cesar database of French plays, ie. works with a farcical element, originally intended to be performed outside the theatre to entice audiences to enter. Like other dramatic terms in the database, these terms tend to be drawn from the works themselves, either directly from titles or title-pages, or indirectly through the César database. A sub-category of ‘Literature’ + ‘Drama’ + ‘Comedy’.

Business Correspondence.definition: Works on the art and conventions of writing business letters. A sub-category of ‘Economics’ + ‘Commerce’ and ‘Writing (art of)’

Bussy-Rabutin, Roger de.definition: French nobleman celebrated and disgraced for his scandalous amorous history of the Gauls, written under Louis XIV.

Byzantium.definition: Can refer both to Byzantium or the Byzantine empire.

Cagliostro.definition: Alias of Guiseppe Balsamo, a Neapolitan Charlatan and freemason best known for his alchemical experiments, séances and involvement in the diamond necklace affair.

Calas, Jean.definition: Protestant victim of a notorious miscarriage of justice, executed in 1762, he was posthumously pardoned following a campaign led by Voltaire.

Calonne, Charles-Alexandre de.definition: French finance minister and arch-rival of Necker.

Calvin, Jean.definition: Swiss divine. Founder of Calvinist branch of Christianity during Protestant reformation.

Calvinism.definition: A work which takes the Calvinist faith, practices and / or worshippers as an object of study. ‘Calvinism’ is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Protestantism’.

Camisard Revolt.definition: Works relating to the Camisard revolt. A sub-category of ‘History’ + ‘France’ + ‘Huguenots’.

Canals.definition: Works relating to the building, uses, or navigation of canals.

Canon Law.definition: Works treating or recording the codified laws of the Christian Church. ‘Canon Law’ is a sub-category of ‘Law’ and usually take the keywords ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ as well. (the exceptions are usually general works which touch on canon law).

Capello, Bianca.definition: Italian renaissance noblewoman (lived 1548-87). Mistress and later wife of Francesco I de Medici, and hence duchess of Florence.

Card Games.definition: Books relating to the playing and / or rules of card games. A sub-category of ‘Hobbies and pastimes’.

Caribbean.definition: This region includes all the islands generally known as the West Indies.

Caricature & Comic Art.definition: Works of or relating to caricature and comic art.

Caroline, Queen of Denmark.definition: Also known as Caroline Mathilde, (lived 1751-1775); daughter of Frederick, Prince of Wales; wife of Christian VII of Denmark, who in 1772 divorced her following the disgrace of Struensee, Caroline’s lover.

Carthage.definition: Can refer to both the city and empire of Carthage.

Cartography.definition: Works relating to mapmaking and / or the drawing and production of maps.

Castaway tales.definition: Stories of the adventures of castaways, fictitious or real. In fiction this genre was established and largely inspired by Robinson Crusoe.

Casuistry.definition: Works discussing, denouncing or satirising the religious / moral standpoint known as Casuistry.

Catalogue.definition: Catalogue listings of collections of items. Catalogues are a ‘sub-category’ of ‘Reference work’. There are the following sub-categories of ‘Catalogue’: ‘trade catalogue’, ‘private collection catalogue’, ‘public collection catalogue’.

Catechisms.definition: Christian catechisms. Other works in the form of catechisms are not categorised under this heading. ‘Catechisms’ is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ +  ‘Christian doctrine’. All ‘Catechisms’ are also by definition ‘Works of Religiosity.’

Catherine II.definition: Empress of Russia, also known as Catherine the Great, ruled 1762-1796.

Catholic text.definition: A work, be it a sacred text, religious polemic or other work, which because of its ideological content (including translations of scripture) can be strongly identified with the Roman Catholic faith. Such works are by definition ‘Works of Religiosity’.

Catholicism.definition: A work which takes the Roman Catholic faith, practices and / or worshippers as an object of study. ‘Catholicism’ is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ and ‘Christianity’.

Cato.definition: Refers to Cato the Elder, the Roman Statesman and soldier.

Causes celebres.definition: Works concerning notorious legal cases / judgments.

Celibacy.definition: Works relating to celibacy (whether or not religiously inspired) as a practice or moral choice.

Celtic Church.definition: Works relating to the history or practices of the Celtic Church in Britain or Ireland. A sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’.

Censorship.definition: Works discussing or relating to the practice of censorship.

Ceramics.definition: Works discussing ceramics. ‘Ceramics’ is a sub-category of ‘Fine Arts’.

Charity.definition: Works discussing and / or recommending charitable acts or giving. Usually religious or moral in nature.

Charlatans.definition: Works discussing charlatans, either individually or en masse.

Charlemagne.definition: Medieval Frankish king, founder of Holy Roman Empire. Ruled 768-814.

Charles II of Great Britain.definition: Ruled Britain from the Restoration in 1660 until his death in 1685.

Charles III of Spain.definition: King of Spain, 1759-1788. Previously, from 1735, King of Naples and Sicily.

Charles IX of France.definition: King of France from 1760-1774. Notorious as the king presiding over the Saint Bartholomew’s day Massacre of protestants in 1768.

Charles V.definition: Early sixteenth century King of Spain and Holy Roman Emperor.

Charles XII.definition: King of Sweden, ruled 1697-1718. Known for his ultimately unsuccessful invasion of Russia during the Great Northern War.

Chemistry.definition: Works treating the science or practical aspects of chemistry. ‘Chemistry’ is a sub-category of ‘Science’.

Childhood diseases.definition: Works of medical pathology addressing childhood diseases. ‘Childhood diseases’ is a sub-category of ‘Science’ + ‘Medicine’.

Child-rearing.definition: Works relating to raising children (as opposed to educating them).

Children's literature.definition: Works, literary or otherwise, aimed primarily at children and young people.

Chiropody.definition: Works of medical pathology or anatomy concerned with the treatment of minor ailments of the foot. ‘Chiropody’ is a sub-category of ‘Medicine’ + ‘Science’.

Chivalric Orders.definition: Works devoted to the history or activities of Orders of Chivalry. A sub-category of ‘Chivalry’.

Chocolate.definition: Works relating to Chocolate. A sub-category of ‘Food and Beverages’.

Christian Doctrine.definition: Works devoted to Christian doctrine, whether explicatory or as an object of study. This keyword is ideologically neutral and its use does not necessarily imply sympathy with Christian teachings. Cf. the ideological keywords ‘Work of Religiosity’ and ‘Sceptical Work’, which are used for works with pro- and anti- Christian sympathies respectively. A sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’.

Christian enlightenment text.definition: ‘Works of religiosity’ produced by Christian writers strongly associated with the enlightenment or whose means of arguing and writing strategies emulate those of enlightenment writers.

Christian life.definition: Religious works explaining how to live a virtuous Christian life. ‘Christian life’ is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’. Works with this keyword are, by definition, ‘Works of religiosity’.

Christian Rulership.definition: Works treating the morals, duties, obligations and practices of Christian monarchs. A sub-category of ‘Politics’ and ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’.

Christian theology.definition: Speculative works [as opposed to sacred texts or works on Christian doctrine] discussing or speculating on the nature and/ or existence of God written by writers with a Christian viewpoint. ‘Christian theology’ ’ is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ and ‘Theology’. This keyword is not entirely subsumed within the category ‘Christianity’, as the belief systems of the author may be heterodox or ideosyncratic or expounded as a refutation of an alien system rather than an exposition of Christian belief.

Christianity.definition: Works (including satirical or anti-clerical works) relating to the study, beliefs and / or practices of Christian faith(s) and those who practice the same. This term is ideogically neutral, cf. ‘Apologetic works’; ‘Sceptical works’. (NB Scriptures sacred to both the Jewish and Christian faiths are designated under Christianity but not Judaism). ‘Christianity’ is a sub-category of ‘Religion’.

Christina, Queen of Sweden.definition: Mid-seventeenth century Queen of Sweden, famous for her renunciation of Protestantism and the throne in 1654.

Chronology.definition: Works devoted to establishing (mainly ancient or Biblical) chronology on an empirical footing. [this means that chronological appoaches to later historical writing do not normally come under this category]

Church and State.definition: Works dealing with the historical or contemporary eighteenth century relations between Church (or organised religion) and the State. The use of this keyword does not indicate an author’s ideological preferences on the question. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Religion’.

Church History.definition: Works relating to the history of the Christian Church(es). Usually employed as a sub-category of ‘Religion’ and ‘History’ (though occasionally ‘Historical drama’ or ‘Historical Fiction’).

Civil Law.definition: Works relating to the Civil Law or important aspects thereof.  A sub-category of ‘Law’.

Classical antiquity.definition: Works treating the classical world as their subject

Classical remains.definition: Works relating to the remains of classical buildings and other works of antiquity. Accompanies the keyword ‘Classical antiquity’ where these are the major focus of a work.

Clement XIV, Pope.definition: Controversial enlightenment Pope from 1769-1774, his pontificate saw attempts to reconcile spiritual and temporal authority in the Catholic world, as well as the decree dissolving the Jesuit order.

Clerical jurisdiction.definition: Works treating the legal details, nature or extent of the clergy’s legal authority, particularly over secular matters. ‘Clerical jurisdiction’ is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ and ‘Church and State’ and ‘Law’.

Coach Services.definition: Works largely devoted to the details (routes; timetables; functions) of commercial coach and carriage services.

Coachmanship.definition: Works relating to the driving and / or maintenance of coaches.

Cocoa.definition: Works relating to Cocoa. A sub-category of ‘Food and Beverages.’

Coffee.definition: Works relating to Coffee. A sub-category of ‘Food and Beverages.’

Colbert, Jean-Baptiste.definition: Celebrated government minister of Louis XIV.

Collected works.definition: This is a catch all term to describe volumes containing more than one work, whether by one or more author, and regardless of whether the volumes are anthologies or essays addressing a common theme, or written on diverse topics. Collections of short stories or poems by a single author intended for publication together have not typically been styled ‘Collected works’.

Colonial policy.definition: Works discussing the colonial policy of one or more states.

Combustion.definition: Works relating to the burning of fuels and the uses of this process.

Comedy.definition: Dramatic literary works fitting the eighteenth-century definition of the French term Comédie: i.e a theatrical piece ‘in which is represented a scene from everyday life, that is supposed to have passed between persons of private condition’ (Dictionnaire de l’Académie française, 1762). It follows from this that not all comedies are comic or humorous; those that are have been indicated, wherever detected, by the keyword ‘Satirical Works’. As with other dramatic keywords, the use of the term Comedy usually derives from its use in the César database, which in turn tends to be derived from the title page of the work in question. ‘Comedy’ is a sub-category of ‘Literature’ + ‘Drama’.

Comets.definition: Works relating to comets and meteors. A sub-category of ‘Astronomy’.

Comic Opera.definition: This keyword is used for light-hearted operatic works. Most are identified as Comic Opera from the title-page of a copy of the work or through the CESAR database, which draws on title pages for its genre descriptions. ‘Comic Opera’ is a sub-category of the keywords ‘Music’ + 'Opera': such works are also identified as ‘Literature’ + ‘Drama’.

Comic Poetry.definition: Sub-category of ‘Literature’ + ‘Poetry’ comprising humorous poems. Usually also carry the keyword ‘satirical works’ (q.v.).

Commerce.definition: Works relating to trade in goods or services. Where these works are discursive of commerce, they also take the sub-category of ‘Economics’; trade manuals as a rule do not.

Commercial Law.definition: Works relating to commercial law. A sub-category of ‘Law’ and ‘Commerce’ + ‘Economics’.

Communication Routes.definition: Works offering detailed descriptions and practical information about communications routes.

Communion.definition: Works relating to or treating Holy Communion, potentially ranging from service books to theological tracts to satires on the Mass. A sub-category of ‘Religion’ and ‘Christianity’.

Compagnie des Indes.definition: Works dealing with the French colonial trading outfit known as the Compagnie des Indes.

Comte d'Estaing.definition: Charles Hector, comte d'Estaing. French general and admiral (1729-1794)

Concordances and Biblical Dictionaries.definition: Reference works serving as Biblical Concordances or Dictionaries of the Bible. Sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ + ‘Biblical Study’ and ‘Reference works’ + ‘Dictionary’.

Conduct manual.definition: Works whose primary or major function is to advise readers on the appropriate behaviour, moral conduct and / or social ettiquette.

Confessions of Rousseau.definition: Works discussing Rousseau’s celebrated autobiographical Confessions. A ‘sub-category of ‘Rousseau’ and ‘Lives and Letters’.

Conquistadors.definition: Works of fact or fiction treating the Spanish conquerors of the New World.

Conseils Souverains.definition: Works relating to or emanating from the Sovereign Councils of French provinces. A sub-category of ‘France’.

Constitutional theory.definition: Works relating to the theory of constitutions and how they operate. A sub-category of ‘Politics’ + ‘Political Theory’.

Constitutions.definition: Publications primarily comprising of the texts of political constitutions or laws of a constitutional nature.

Convent literature.definition: Literary works set in convent / monastic settings as a device to attack monasticism and / or convey an erotic charge. A sub-category of ‘Literature’ and of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ + ‘Catholicism’ + ‘Religious Orders’. Usually also ‘erotic works’. For non-fiction works on monastic communities (including non-Christian ones), see ‘Monasticism’.

Conversation (art of).definition: Works relating to the art of social conversation. A sub-category of ‘Languages’.

Conversion narratives.definition: A genre of narrative works describing the religious conversion experience of [usually Protestant] Christian believers.  A sub-category of ‘Lives and Letters’ + ‘Biography’ and ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’.

Cookery.definition: Works relating to cooking. Note also the key-words recipes and nutrition. A sub-category of ‘Household Skills’.

Corneille, Pierre.definition: French seventeenth-century dramatist, writer of tragedies.

Correspondence.definition: Non-fiction works comprised primarily of the correspondence of [usually well-known] figures. ‘Correspondence’ is a sub-category of ‘Lives and Letters’. This keyword’s several sub-categories include ‘Historical Correspondence’; ‘Political Correspondence’; ‘Literary Correspondence’; ‘Scientific Correspondence’.

Corsairs.definition: Works relating to Corsairs and Pirates.

Corsets.definition: Works treating corsets as their subject matter.  A sub-category of ‘Fashion’.

Corsica.definition: Can refer to both the island and the (short-lived) kingdom of Corsica.

Cosmetics.definition: Works relating to cosmetics and beauty products. Cf. ‘Beauty’.

Cosmology.definition: Works devoted to explaining or studying the cosmos.

Costume.definition: Works relating to costume, dress and adornment.

Courts & Courtiers.definition: Works offering detailed descriptions of the life of the royal court or lives of courtiers. This keyword covers a wide range of genres, from romances and allegorical political novels through to scandalous memoirs, via collections of anecdote, biography, mémoires and history.

Criminal biography.definition: Genre of biography recounting the life of a celebrated (and usually condemned) criminal. A sub-category of ‘Lives and Letters’ + ‘Biography’.

Criminal Law.definition: Works treating the criminal law.  ‘Criminal Law’ is a sub-category of ‘Law’.

Cromwell, Oliver.definition: British parliamentarian and general, he was made Lord Protector following the English civil wars of 1642-8 and execution of Charles I.

Crop Failure.definition: Works relating to the causes and/ or consequences of crop failure. A sub-category of ‘Agriculture’.

Cultural news.definition: Works devoted to the communication of diverse and miscellaneous snippets of cultural news, typically covering celebrated authors, theatrical life and performances and the social and cultural life of the Court. Genres associated with ‘Cultural news’ include ‘Chroniques scandaleuses’; published but formerly clandestine manuscript newsletters.

Cuneiform.definition: Works relating to the Cuneiform system of writing. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Languages’.

Customary Law.definition: Works treating customary law. ‘Customary Law’ is a sub-category of ‘Law’,

Customs duties.definition: Works treating customs duties. For related themes see also ‘Prices and Tariffs’. A sub-category of ‘Taxation’.

Dancing.definition: Works relating to dancing, including works of dance drama and ballet, as well as non-fiction works.

Dark Ages.definition: Works relating to the (approximate) chronological period between the fall of the Roman Empire and the apogee of the Carolingian empire under Charlemagne.

Deaf-mutes.definition: Works devoted to the discussion of persons who can neither hear or speak.

Death and dying.definition: Works discussing death and / or the process of dying.

Deism.definition: Works exploring, treating or expounding Atheism. Does not imply ideological sympathies, cf. ‘sceptical works’; ‘deist works’. ‘Deism’ is a sub-category of ‘Religion’.

Deist work.definition: Works supporting and expounding deist ideas (ie. non-doctrinal belief in an abstract beneficent God), or widely conceived by contemporaries to support and expound them. Although the keywords ‘Deist work’ and ‘Atheist work’ are theoretically incompatible within a single author work, certain anthologies contain works of both tendencies.

Demography.definition: Works relating to population and its study.

Demonology.definition: Works dealing with the subject of demons, devils etc., including fictional or satirical works with devils as major characters.

Denmark.definition: Can refer to Denmark in both its geographic sense and its empire, which at the time covered by this database included Norway.

Dentistry.definition: Scientific medical works on the care, diseases and treatment of the teeth.

Descartes.definition: Early seventeenth century French mathematician and philosopher.

Despotism.definition: Ideological term. Used for works treating and denouncing political despotism. NB. Not all works in this category carry the keyword ‘Politics’ – eg. those primarily concerned with the penal system.

Devotional manual.definition: Works for use in private Christian religious devotions. ‘Devotional Manual’ is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ + ‘Sacred Text’.

Dialogues of the Dead.definition: Works recounting (necessarily fictitious) conversations with or between dead persons.

Diamond Necklace Affair.definition: Works relating to the celebrated French scandal known as the Diamond Necklace Affair, which broke in 1785. The affair related to a group of fraudsters led by the comte and comtesse de La Motte successfully forging Queen Marie-Antoinette’s signature to acquire a fabulous diamond necklace affair. It took on a political dimension when King Louis XVI ordered a public trial to clear the Queen’s name, having arrested her distant kinsman, Cardinal de Rohan, on suspicion of complicity in the fraud. In the political trial that followed, Rohan was acquitted having relied on a defence that impugned the Queen’s morals. The comtesse de La Motte later capitalised on this by producing scandalous and entirely mendacious accounts of the Queen’s sex life. Another figure in the affair, ‘Cagliostro’ has his own keyword in the database (qv.) and books about him may touch on the affair, even if they do not carry the keyword ‘Diamond Necklace Affair’. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’ and ‘Causes celeb

Dictionary.definition: Reference books offering articles in strict alphabetical order on various subjects, included but not limited to language dictionaries. General ‘Encyclopaedia’ and collections of essays presented in alphabetical order of arbitrary title (such as Voltaire’s Dictionnaire philosophique) are not included in this category. Language dictionaries can be isolated by using the keyword combination ‘Dictionary’ + (e.g.) ‘French language’; the Parisian keyword ‘Grammaires et dictionnaires’ is also useful here.

Didactic Fiction.definition: Fictional works of ‘Literature’ which have an explicit/clearly stated or evident didactic purpose (since most fiction has some didactic purpose, a strong statement is necessary for this category). ‘Didactic fiction’ is a rare case where fictional works have been attributed non-fictional subjects. NB. the use of this keyword is indicative only – no systematic attempt has been made to identify every work that might be so categorised.

Digestion.definition: Works concerning the process of digestion. A sub-category of ‘Science’ + ‘Biology’ + ‘Physiology’.

Distillation.definition: Works relating to the preparation of liquors and other liquids that need to be distilled.

Diverse non-European countries.definition: Works treating issues in a miscellaneous group of countries beyond Europe, a group to small to be considered global and too broad and miscellaneous to be included in a short list of countries or regions.

Divine Judgement.definition: Works treating the question of the last judgment of the human soul by the divinity. A sub-category of ‘Religion’.

Divorce.definition: Works focusing on the legal aspects of divorce, or on produced as part of particular divorce cases (eg. the legal briefs of one or both partners). NB. For a related marital scandal (including a divorce) that is very prominent in the database see ‘Rilliet affair’. The Rilliet works are not tagged as being about ‘divorce’.

Drama.definition: This category covers all works written for performance on the stage (including ‘Opera’ or ‘Ballet’). The use of the keyword ‘Drama’ to describe a single work is mutually exclusive with the keyword ‘Poetry’ (but anthologies and collected works may have both keywords applied to separate works within them). NB. Dramatic works written in verse are not categorised as ‘Poetry’ in the keyword system used here: instead they are recorded as ‘Verse Drama’. However, all plays appear under the category ‘Poetique’ in the Parisian booksellers’ system of categorisation, (ie. the alternative system used in this database). ‘Drama’ is a sub-category of ‘Literature.’

Drame.definition: Dramatic literary works revolving around a single principal event (‘action’), which though on serious subjects often, though not invariably, depict ordinary (generally bourgeois) people and their lives. These have been identified via their title-pages or through the CESAR database, where they are described as such. The French term Drame is used because there is no exact equivalent in English. The 1835 edition of the Dictionnaire de l’Académie française described a Drame thus:  ‘Pièce de théâtre, en vers ou en prose, d'un genre mixte entre la tragédie et la comédie, dont l'action, sérieuse par le fond, souvent familière par la forme, admet toutes sortes de personnages, ainsi que tous les sentiments et tous les tons.’ Like other dramatic terms in the database, this category tend to be drawn from the works themselves, either directly from titles or title-pages, or indirectly through the César database. A sub-category of the keywords ‘Literature’ + ‘Drama’.

Drawing.definition: Works treating the Art of Drawing or containing Drawings. A sub-category of ‘Fine Arts’.

Dreams (interpretation of).definition: Works claiming to explain or provide guidelines for discerning the meaning of dreams.

Droz, Jaquet.definition: The work with this keyword may relate to the Jacquet Droz watchmakers, founded in 1738. However, the archival reference is not sufficiently clear for this to be certain.

du Barry, Jeanne.definition: Last and distinctly plebian mistress of King Louis XV of France. She was executed during the French revolution.

Dutch Language.definition: Works relating to the vocabulary, use, grammatical rules, study or teaching of the Dutch language, including grammars, dictionaries, vocabulary, rhetoric, style and composition etc.. Related keywords include ‘languages’, ‘grammar’, ‘dictionary’, ‘rhetoric’, ‘art of writing’.

Dyes and tinctures.definition: Works relating to the preparation or use of dyes and tinctures. Related keyword categories include: ‘recipes’, ‘painting’.

Dysentery.definition: Works dealing with the disease known as dysentery.

Ecclesiastical affairs.definition: Works treating or emanating from the secular affairs and disputes of the Christian Churches. A sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’.

Ecclesiastical Property.definition: Works relating to Ecclesiastical Property. A sub-category of ‘Property’ and ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’.

Ecclesiastical reform.definition: Works treating the question of to Ecclesiastical reform. Most such works would advocate such reform. A sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’.

Economic Theory.definition: Works treating matters of economic theory; a sub-category of ‘Economics.’

Economics.definition: Catch all term for works relating to economics and the economy. Its sub-categories and related terms include ‘Commerce’, ‘Agronomy’, ‘Manufacturing’, ‘International trade’, ‘Economic theory’, and ‘Industry’, as well as ‘Financial Administration’, ‘Financial speculation’; ‘Colonial policy’; and ‘Banking’.

Ecumenicalism.definition: Works treating Ecumenicalism. A sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’.

Edicts.definition: Published texts of government edicts or proclamations. ‘Edicts’ is a sub-category of ‘Official documents’.

Education of Princes.definition: Works treating the Education of Princes. A sub-category of ‘Education’.

Educational Curriculum.definition: Works relating to the Educational Curriculum. A sub-category of ‘Education’.

Electricity.definition: Works relating to Electricity. A sub-category of ‘Science’ + ‘Physics’.

Elizabeth I of England.definition: Ruled 1558-1603 and celebrated above all for the victory of her fleets over the Spanish Armada of 1588.

Embroidery.definition: Works relating to Embroidery. A sub-category of ‘Household skills’.

Encyclopaedia.definition: Works of general reference or on specific subjects organised systematically in alphabetical order of topic heading, and which aspire to give a comprehensive overview of the fields covered. Collections of essays arranged by arbitrarily assigned alphabetical title such as Voltaire’s Philosophical Dictionary are not included under this keyword.

England.definition: Works relating specifically to England. The keyword ‘Britain’ is always used alongside England, in part to reflect ambiguous usage of the word ‘Angleterre’.

English Language.definition: Works relating to the vocabulary, use, grammatical rules, study or teaching of the English language, including grammars, dictionaries, vocabulary, rhetoric, style and composition etc.. Related keywords include ‘grammar’, ‘dictionary’, ‘rhetoric’, ‘art of writing’, and ‘Languages’.

Engraving.definition: Works relating to Engraving. A sub-category of ‘Fine Arts’.

Entomology.definition: Scientific works concerning the study of insects, a sub-category of ‘Science’ + ‘Biology’. See also the keyword definitions ‘Biology’, ‘Natural History (general)’.

Epic Poetry.definition: Poetic works identified as detailing works of heroism important to a particular nation or culture. A sub-category of ‘Literature’ + ‘Poetry’.

Epidemiology.definition: Works discussing epidemic diseases and their outbreaks. A sub-category of ‘Science’ + ‘Medicine’.

Epigrams.definition: Poetic works identified as containing collections of epigrams. ‘Epigrams’ is a sub-category of ‘Literature’ and ‘Poetry’.

Epistemology.definition: Works treating with the theory of knowledge. A sub-category of Philosophy.

Epistolary Fiction.definition: Works of creative literature written in the form of letters between protagonists in the story. A sub-category of ‘Literature’ + ‘Prose fiction’.

Equestrianism.definition: Works treating the art of horseriding. A sub-category of ‘Horsemanship’.

Equine care.definition: Works treating the art of caring for horses, whether from the perspective of ‘Veterinary Science’ or ‘Animal Husbandry’ or both.

Erotic works.definition: Broad category covering works designed to have an erotic charge, ranging from outright pornography (ie works which offer descriptions of genitals or the sexual act for the purposes of titillation) through to works which allude frequently to sexualised activities or pleasures, without necessarily offering graphic explicit passages.

Espionage.definition: Works relating to espionage and spies, including police agents. Quite often linked to politics.

Etiquette.definition: Works relating to Etiquette. See also ‘Conduct Manual’.

Exchange Rates.definition: Works discussing or recording Exchange Rates. Usually associated with the keyword ‘Commerce’.

Exploration.definition: Works relating to European journeys of discovery in other parts of the globe.

Explosives.definition: Works relating to Explosives, their manufacture and uses, whether industrial or military.

Fables.definition: Fables; fabulous stories in verse or prose, narrative or dramatic form, intended for diversion and moral instruction. (Fables are usually encountered in anthologies, hence use of the plural form). A sub-category of ‘Literature’.

Fairy Tales.definition: Fairy Tales – fantastic and magical tales aimed mostly at children. (NB. These were a new genre in the mid-eighteenth-century). A sub-category of ‘Literature’.

Falconry.definition: Works relating to Falconry. A sub-category of ‘Hunting’.

Family relationships.definition: Non-fiction works relating to family relationships.

Famine.definition: Non fiction works relating to Famine.

Fantasy adventures.definition: Sustained works of narrative fiction describing adventures involving magical beings or similar fantastical elements. Unlikely fairy tales these were not aimed primarily at a child audience. A sub-category of ‘Literature’.

Fenelon.definition: François Fénelon, French archbishop, theologian, and writer, died 1715.

Fernando Cortes.definition: Conquistador famed for his conquest of the Aztec kingdom in Mexico.

Feudal dues.definition: Works treating the topic of feudal dues.

Fictionalised biography.definition: Biographical works identified as including substantial and usually transparent sections which are best thought of as creative fiction rather than true biography. The list of works under this category should be considered indicative rather than comprehensive. To qualify for this category, fictional content needs to extend beyond improbable claims or passages which are clearly false, contrived or based on gossip and slander (as for example in accounts of the early life of previously obscure individuals such as Du Barry) or even completely mendacious (as in Madame La Motte’s accounts of the Diamond Necklace Affair and her relationship with Marie-Antoinette). Cf. the keyword ‘Spurious works’.

Financial administration.definition: Works treating the raising and use of state finances. Usually accompanied by the keywords ‘Politics’ and ‘Economics’.

Financial Appeals.definition: Printed works that appeal for financial contributions for a particular cause; charitable appeals.

Financial Speculation.definition: Works discussing the practice of financial speculation and / or speculators.

Fine Arts.definition: Works related to both the production and products of the fine arts. Major sub-categories include ‘Drawing’, ‘Sculpture’, ‘Painting’, ‘Architecture’, ‘Prints’, ‘Ceramics’, ‘Religious art’.

Fire prevention.definition: Works treating means to prevent the outbreak or spread of fires.

Fishing.definition: Works relating to fishing, whether as a hobby or industry.

Flatulence.definition: Works that deal with flatulence, whether from medical / physiological or humorous perspectives.

Fleury, Cardinal de.definition: French cardinal and chief minister in the first half of the reign of Louis XV.

Floriculture.definition: Works relating to the production of flowers. A sub-category of ‘Agriculture’.

Folk Legends.definition: Works recounting popular but widely accepted myths. Qv. ‘Mythology’.

Food and Beverages.definition: Works dealing with foodstuffs or drinks, their manufacture, preparation, uses and consumption. Note: works on the cultivation of food crops or raising of animals for meat are treated are found under keywords ‘arable farming’ and ‘animal husbandry’.

Food preservation.definition: Works discussing methods of preserving food.

Forces lists.definition: Official documents listing all or part of the army and/or naval forces of a state or states. A sub-category of ‘Official documents’ and ‘Military affairs’.

Fortifications.definition: Works relating to the construction and use of Fortifications. For the means of attacking, defending, taking or destroying fortifications, see also the keyword ‘siege warfare’. The keyword ‘Fortifications’ is a sub-category of ‘Military affairs’.

France.definition: Is generally used to refer to the Bourbon kingdom of France, but occasionally maybe used in a looser geographic sense (particularly in historical contexts).

Francophonie.definition: Works treating and promoting the superiority of the French language over others and / or arguing for its adoption as a universal language.

Franklin, Benjamin.definition: American printer, writer, scientist, statesman and polymath. A founding father of the United States.

Frederick II of Prussia.definition: Also known as Frederick the Great, ruled 1740-1786. Also ruler of principality of Neuchâtel.

Frederick William II.definition: King of Prussia and ruler of Neuchâtel, 1786-1797.

Free trade.definition: Works discussing or advocating the principles of free trade. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Economics’.

Freedom of the Press.definition: Works discussing or advocating the principle of press liberty.

French language.definition: Works relating to the vocabulary, use, grammatical rules, study or teaching of the French language, including grammars, dictionaries, vocabulary, rhetoric, style and composition etc.. Related keywords include ‘grammar’, ‘dictionary’, ‘rhetoric’, ‘art of writing’, and ‘Languages’.

French Revolution.definition: Political works discussing the French revolution. Works in this category range from political pamplets and contemporary history through to scandalous sexual libelles against Queen Marie-Antoinette. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Politics’ + ‘Current Affairs’ and ‘France’.

Fribourg.definition: Can refer to both the town or Canton of Fribourg in Switzerland.

Friendship.definition: Works treating the subject of Friendship. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Emotions and sentiments’.

Fronde rebellion.definition: Works relating to the Fronde rebellions of the mid-seventeenth century.

Fuels.definition: Works relating to the production, supply and use of combustible fuels.

Funereal oration.definition: Works belonging to the genre known as ‘funereal orations’. These were published speeches prepared to mark the death of a great figure and, generally, to praise their virtues. The tradition dates back at least to ancient Greece, where it was expected to combine a eulogy to the dead with an exhortation to the living. Although in this database a sub-category of ‘Lives and Letters’ and ‘Biography’, the biographical component might be relatively limited, taking the form of panegyric subsumed within a wider religious sermon or moral lecture. By the eighteenth  century, published funereal orations were not necessarily delivered at the funeral of the person whose passing they marked, and the death of some public figures was marked by the publication of several official and non-official orations.

Futuristic tales.definition: Works of creative fiction set wholly or partly in an imagined far future. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Literature’.

Gallicanism.definition: Works treating or advocating Gallican religious ideas and / or the history of  Gallicanism. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ +_ ‘Catholicism’ and ‘France’.

Gambling.definition: Works relating to gambling, whether as a pastime or cause for social comment or concern.

Garden design.definition: Works relating to the aesthetic and practical considerations of designing, laying out and planting large scale gardens, whether for private (eg. for chateaux or country houses) or public enjoyment. A sub-category of ‘Gardening’.

Gardening.definition: Works discussing gardening in any of its aspects.

Gases.definition: Works relating to gases, their study, and their chemical or physical properties. A sub-category of ‘Science’ and ‘Chemistry’. NB. Works relating to [Hot Air] ‘Ballooning’ are treated as a separate category.

Gender relations.definition: Works relating to power relations between and status of the sexes. Cf. Nature of women.

Genealogy.definition: Works discussing genealogy in general or offering the genealogies of individuals, families or groups.

General Science.definition: Works treating ‘Science’ in general, rather than being devoted to one or two disciplinary sub-categories (as they were perceived in the eighteenth century). These often tend to be wide-ranging school text books or scientific or general reference works. Note that works devoted (solely) to the multiple branches of natural history are generally only denoted by the keyword ‘Natural history (general)’.

Generalship.definition: Works treating the art of military leadership and how to exercise it (particularly in land warfare). Works in this category do not necessarily treat questions of ‘Strategy and Tactics’, which are dealt with as a separate keyword category in this database. Will normally take either the keywords ‘Military Affairs’ or ‘Military History’ (q.v.).

Geneva.definition: Can refer to both the town or territory of Geneva in Switzerland. At the time covered by this database Geneva was an independent city state and perpetual ally of the Helvetic Confederation (rather than a full member).

Genius.definition: Works treating the subject of individual or creative Genius.

Geography.definition: Works relating to the systematic ‘scientific’ geographic study of the world or some part of it. Distinct from ‘Travels’ which usually lack the system and scientific rigour of geography though the two are not mutually exclusive.

Geography of Religions.definition: Works treating the Geography of Religion.

Geology.definition: Works of science treating the formation and nature of the Earth’s crust, particularly rocks.

George Germain (Lord).definition: British soldier and politician, Secretary of State for America during the American revolutionary war.

George III.definition: King of Britain and Elector of Hanover, 1760-1820.

German language.definition: Works relating to the vocabulary, use, grammatical rules, study or teaching of the German language, including grammars, dictionaries, vocabulary, rhetoric, style and composition etc.. Related keywords include ‘grammar’, ‘dictionary’, ‘rhetoric’, ‘art of writing’, and ‘Languages’.

German Literature.definition: Works of literary history or criticism with a focus on German Literature.

Germany.definition: Is used to refer to Germany or the central territories of the Holy Roman Empire more generally or to works relating to regions or states within it.

Glarus.definition: Works relating to canton of Glarus in Switzerland, part of the Swiss Confederation.

Glass-making and Glassware.definition: Works relating to Glass-making and Glassware

Glorious Revolution.definition: Works relating to the Glorious Revolution of 1688-1689 in Britain.

Goezman affair.definition: Works relating to or produced by either side in the cause célèbre known as the Goëzman affair, a legal and pamphleteering battle between the magistrate Louis-Valentin Goëzman and the playwright and secret agent Pierre-Augustin Caron de Beaumarchais. A sub-category of ‘Law’ and ‘Causes celebres’.

Gospels (non-canonical).definition: Works containing or treating the early Christian accounts of the life of Jesus Christ known as non-canonical Gospels (ie. those which were omitted from the Christian Bible in the course of its compilation). Those containing the actual texts of the non-canonical gospels will be indicated by the simultaneous use of keywords ‘Sacred texts’ and ‘Scriptures’ alongside the keyword ‘Gospels (non-canonical)’. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’.

Gourville, J.-H..definition: Jean-Hérault de Gourville, 1642-1698, courtier and councillor of State under Louis XIV.

Grain Trade.definition: Works relating to the production, distribution, preservation, milling, wholesaling and retailing of grain. For works on grain-derived foodstuffs and drinks, see ‘Food and Beveridges’. Works dealing with the cultivation of grain will be found under the keywords ‘Arable farming’ and ‘Agriculture’.

Grammar.definition: Educational or Reference works treating the grammatical structures of one or more languages. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Languages’.

Gravitation.definition: Works relating to the theory of Gravitation.  This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Science’ + ‘Physics’ + ‘Mechanics’.

Great Northern War.definition: Works relating to the international conflict of 1700-1721 in Northern Europe, particularly between Sweden and Russia, and generally known as the Great Northern war.

Greece.definition: Can refer to both modern and classical Greece. Note that there is a separate keyword for Byzantium.

Greek language.definition: Works relating to the vocabulary, use, grammatical rules, study or teaching of the Greek language, including grammars, dictionaries, vocabulary, rhetoric, style and composition etc.. Related keywords include ‘grammar’, ‘dictionary’, ‘rhetoric’, ‘art of writing’, and ‘Languages’.

Grisons.definition: Refers to this Swiss region, which at the time covered by the database was an independent confederation of three leagues allied to the Swiss confederation.

Guidebooks.definition: Travel literature designed to inform (leisured) travellers about the sites, attractions, amusements and culture of a particular destination. With the growth of the Grand Tour in the eighteenth century, demand for such works had greatly increased. A sub-category of ‘Travel’.

Guines affair.definition: Works relating to or produced by either side in the late 1770s cause célèbre known as the Guines affair, a legal and pamphleteering battle between the French ambassador to London (the Duc de Guines) and his secretary Barthélemy Tort. The case stemmed from the latter’s corrupt involvement with financial speculators and his subsequent allegations that Guines was also involved. A sub-category of ‘Law’ + ‘Causes celebres’.

Gustavus Adolphus.definition: Early seventeenth-century king of Sweden, famed for his generalship during the Swedish military intervention in the 30 Years War.

Hair-dressing.definition: Works on the art of hair-dressing.

Haller, Albert.definition: Albrecht von Haller, Swiss Scientist and poet, 1708-1777.

Hannibal.definition: Carthaginian general in punic wars against Rome.

Happiness.definition: Works focussing on Happiness as a subject, whether from a moral, philosophic, emotional or literary point of view. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Emotions and sentiments’.

Harness-making.definition: Works relating to the manufacturing of harnesses. A sub-category of ‘Industry’ + ‘Manufacturing’.

Heloise.definition: Celebrated lover of Peter Abelard (qv) and author of letters to him following their mutual exile in the wake of their affair.

Henri II, King of France.definition: Renaissance king of France (ruled 1547 to his death in a jousting tournament in 1559). Husband of Catherine de Medici (qv).

Henri IV.definition: Venerated French king who ended the wars of religion by renouncing but tolerating Protestantism. Ruled from 1589 to his assassination in 1610.

Henry, Prince of Portugal, 'the Navigato.definition: Renaissance prince of Portugal whose sponsorship of voyages of exploration precipitated the age of European discoveries.

Henry, Prince of Prussia.definition: Younger brother to Frederick the Great, lived 1726-1802.

Herbalism.definition: Works relating to the properties and uses of Herbs, particularly for medical purposes. A sub-category of ‘Medicine’ + ‘Medical Remedies’.

Heresy.definition: Works relating to actual or alleged Heresies. For works on the treatment of supposed heretics and the institutions charged with their punishment see the keyword ‘Inquisition’.

Heros and Heroism.definition: Works treating the topic of heroism or Heroes in general.

Hinduism.definition: Works relating to the Hindu religion, its beliefs and teachings, its followers and their religious practices. A sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘World Religions’.

Historical Correspondence.definition: Works containing the correspondence of historical figures, defined in this database as dead persons whose primary historical importance lay before the reign of Louis XV of France. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘History’, ‘Lives and Letters’ + ‘Correspondence’. NB. Works treating events from the start of the reign of Louis XV (in 1715) or whose subjects who were still alive at the era the STN began trading (1769) are covered by the alternative keyword ‘Political Correspondence’. Within our dataset it proved possible to keep these two keywords mutually exclusive.

Historical Drama.definition: Works of dramatic literature treating a particular historical episode or character within a broadly historical framework. A sub-category of ‘Literature’ + ‘Drama’.

Historical Fiction.definition: Works of creative fiction (whether prose or poetry) aspiring to treat a particular historical episode or personalities within a ‘realistic’ historical setting. A sub-category of ‘Literature’.

Historical geography.definition: Works treating the geographies of the human past. A sub-category of both ‘History’ and ‘Geography.’

Historical language dictionaries.definition: Language dictionaries focusing on vocabulary and use of living languages in the historical past. A sub-category of ‘Reference work’ + ‘Dictionary’ and ‘History’ and ‘Languages’.

Historical Methodology.definition: Works treating the methods for researching and / or writing history.

History.definition: Works touching on the history of a society or societies or other defined unit. Contemporary events (defined as those of the reigns of Louis XV and Louis XVI in France are treated under ‘Politics’ + ‘Current Affairs’ not history). The exception is events in the recent past with full closure – eg. The Seven Years War. Usually history is qualified by one or more geographical tags and often also tagged to one or two or three rulers whose reigns spanned the period covered by the history.  Note: histories of academic disciplines such as ‘History of Science’. ‘History of Medicine’ or ‘History of Education’ have not usually been tagged with the keyword ‘History’, nor have works of ‘Literary history’. Equally fictional works with a historical setting, instead of ‘History’ carry the keyword ‘Historical fiction.’

History of Education.definition: Works treating the History of Education. A sub-category of ‘Education’.

History of Mathematics.definition: Works treating the History of Mathematics. A sub-category of ‘Mathematics’.

History of Medicine.definition: Works treating the History of Medicine. A sub-category of ‘Science’ + ‘Medicine’ and ‘History’.

History of Philosophy.definition: Works treating the History of Philosophy. A sub-category of ‘Philosophy’.

History of Science.definition: Works treating the ‘History of Science’. A sub-category of ‘Science’.

Hobbies and Pastimes.definition: Works relating to hobbies, pastimes and entertainments in general.

Homer.definition: Mythical Greek poet and supposed author of the Iliad and Odyssey.

Household Skills.definition: Works describing or treating household skills. Usually such works are reference books and / or manuals.

Huguenots.definition: Works treating the Huguenots, their beliefs and history as subjects of study / discussion. A sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’. NB. Works of Huguenot ideology or piety will be tagged with the keyword ‘Protestant work’.

Human reproduction.definition: Works treating the reproduction of human beings, whether from a formal medical / scientific perspective or the point of view of folklore or pseudo-science.

Hundred Year's War.definition: Works relating to the Hundred Year’s War between England and France.

Hunting.definition: Works treating to the hunting of animals, whether for sport or sustenance.

Hydrography.definition: Works related to the study of bodies of water. This keyword is a sub-category of 'Science'.

Hydro-power.definition: Works concerning the hydraulic powering of machinery or mills. This keyword is a subcategory of 'Science' + 'Physics' + 'Mechanics', 'Industry' + 'Manufacturing', and 'Technology'.

Hygiene.definition: Works relating to the connection between cleanliness and health.

Hymns.definition: Works containing collections of religious songs for use in worship or devotions. This keyword is a sub-categories of ‘Religion’ + ‘Sacred Text’, and such works are almost by definition ‘Works of Religiosity’.

Hypochondria.definition: Works relating to Hypochondria. A sub-category of ‘Medicine’ + ‘Mental Diseases’.

Ile de Bourbon.definition: This was the contemporary name for La Réunion.

Illegitimacy.definition: Works treating the subject of Illegitimacy.

Imagination.definition: Works treating the subject of Imagination.

Incest.definition: Works treating the subject of Incest.

Industry.definition: Works concerned with the processes or commercial enterprise of making products, whether manufactured items, foodstuffs, etc.. Cf. Manufacture.

Infanticide.definition: Works treating the murder of children.

Inheritance.definition: Works treating questions relating to Inheritance. A sub-category of ‘Law.’

Inoculation.definition: Works treating medical inoculation against disease. In the period covered by this database, this related specifically to inoculation against smallpox. This is a sub-category of ‘Science’ + ‘Medicine’.

Inquisition.definition: Works relating to religious Inquisitions, notably the Spanish Inquisition and the Papal Inquisition. A sub-category of ‘Religious persecution’.

Insurance Premiums.definition: Works discussing the principles, details or rates of Insurance Premiums.

International Law.definition: Legal works treating questions relating to conduct of nations towards one another and how that conduct should be regulated. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’.

International relations.definition: Works of ‘Politics’, ‘History’ or ‘Political theory’ treating the political relations between states, whether on a practical, theoretical, satirical or historico-political perspectives. Many of these works relate to questions of contemporary international affairs, wars and crises such as the American revolution.

International Trade.definition: Works treating economic commerce between states, colonies or regions of the world. This is a sub-category of ‘Economics’ + ‘Commerce’.

Ireland.definition: ‘Ireland’ always takes the country tag ‘Britain’ also.

Irreligious works.definition: Works which adopt a hostile attitude and tone towards revealed religion, without offering a detailed philosophic critique. Typically such works go beyond mere anti-clericalism or ribaldry. Cf ‘Sceptical works’; ‘Anti-clerical works’.

Islam.definition: A work which takes the Islamic faith, practices and / or worshippers as an object of study. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Religion’.

Italian language.definition: Works relating to the vocabulary, use, grammatical rules, study or teaching of the Italian language, including grammars, dictionaries, vocabulary, rhetoric, style and composition etc.. Related keywords include ‘grammar’, ‘dictionary’, ‘rhetoric’, ‘art of writing’, and ‘Languages’.

Italian Wars.definition: Works relating to the Italian wars, particularly those of the renaissance period.

Ivan III of Russia.definition: Ruler of Russia, 1462-1505, also known as Ivan the Great.

Jacobitism.definition: Works relating to the history, beliefs and leaders of the Jacobite movement.

James I and VI.definition: Son of Mary Queen of Scots, he inherited the Scottish throne in 1567 and the English throne on the death of Elizabeth in 1603. (Lived 1566-1625).

Jansenism.definition: A work which takes Jansenist belief, practices and / or worshippers as an object of study. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ + ‘Catholicism’.

Jansenist text.definition: A work, be it a secular tract, sacred text or religious polemic, which because of its ideological content (including translations of scripture) can be strongly identified with Jansenist belief. Usually these works take the keywords ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’, but not always. All ‘Jansenist texts’ are by definition ‘Works of Religiosity’.

Jesuits.definition: Works relating to the activities, beliefs or practices of the Society of Jesus and its members. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ + ‘Catholicism’ + ‘Religious Orders.’

Jesus Christ.definition: Founder of Christian religion; recognised by Christians as the son of God and by Muslims as a major prophet.

Jews.definition: A work which relates to the Jewish people and customs. Cf. the keyword ‘Judaism’, which refers to religious beliefs and practices.

Joan of Arc.definition: French national heroine and saint, who claimed to have received divine inspiration and led French armies to victory in several battles in the Hundred Years War, before being captured and executed by the British.

Joseph II.definition: Son of Maria-Theresia. Co-ruler with his mother of Austrian empire from 1765 and sole ruler from 1780-90.

Josephus.definition: Romano-Jewish historian of first century AD.

Judaism.definition: A work which takes the Jewish faith, practices and / or worshippers as an object of study. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Religion’. Cf. the keyword ‘Jews’, which refers to works relating primarily to the Jewish people rather than their faith.

Judicial bodies.definition: Works treating the subject of judicial bodies in general or emanating from such bodies. These works usually take the keyword ‘Law’ and/ or ‘Politics’.

Judicial Memoires.definition: Genre of legal work, created in the course of Judicial Proceedings in order to put the case of one or more protagonists in a legal dispute. In France, in particular, such works enjoyed freedom from censorship, or at least considerable latitude, and it became customary for participants in high profile legal cases to use them to appeal to the ‘tribunal of public opinion’, in the hope of swaying or pressurising judges or discrediting their enemies. Such works were often used, also, for political purposes, and sometimes became best-sellers. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’ and ‘Judicial proceedings’.

Judicial Procedure.definition: Works treating Judicial Procedure as their subject matter. On specific cases, see works with the keyword ‘Judicial proceedings’.  This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’.

Judicial proceedings.definition: Legal works related to or emanating from particular judicial proceedings. NB there is a separate keyword category for ‘Judicial Procedure’. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’.

Julian 'The Apostate'.definition: Last pagan emperor of ancient Rome (ca.331-363)

Jura (Swiss).definition: Refers to the area that would become the Swiss Canton of Jura in 1815, but which at the time covered by this database was part of the Prince-bishopric of Basle.

Keith, Earl-Marechal George.definition: Jacobite general, dispossessed for joining 1715 rebellion.

Kings of France.definition: Works relating to the Kings of France in general. Works on individual kings appear under their names. eg. Louis XV.

Knights Templar.definition: Works relating to the military order known as the Knights of the Temple or Knights Templar. A sub-category of ‘Religion’ + ‘Christianity’ + ‘Catholicism’ + ‘Religious Orders’ and ‘Chivalric Orders’

Kornmann Affair.definition: Works relating to or produced by either side in the ‘Cause célèbre’ known as the Kornmann affair, a legal and pamphleteering battle between the financier Guillaume Kornmann and his much younger wife Catherine Kornmann in 1787-9. The affair began as a simple petition for divorce based upon the wife’s infidelity, but Madame Kornmann defenders, who included Beaumarchais, succeeded in transforming the case into a sexual and political scandal, indicting several leading members of the French government in the process. A sub-category of ‘Law’ and ‘Causes celebres’.

La Barre, Chevalier de.definition: Youthful victim of French blasphemy laws, executed for desecrating a wayside shrine. Voltaire transformed him into a symbol of religious intolerance.

La Fontaine.definition: Jean de la Fontaine, seventeenth-century French fabulist.

La Rochefoucauld, Francois de.definition: Seventeenth-century French author of maxims and memoirs.

La Tour d'Auvergne, F-M de.definition: Seventeenth-century French nobleman and duke de Bouillon, lived 1605-1652. Brother of Turenne (qv.).

Labour Markets.definition: Economic or political treatises relating to the market for Labour.

Lally, General.definition: French general executed following fall of Pondicherry. Voltaire campaigned vociferously for his rehabilitation.

Land improvement.definition: Works treating the means to improve the soils and / or yields of agricultural land. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Economics’, ‘agriculture’, and ‘agronomy’.

Land Tenure.definition: Works relating to the laws or customs of Land Tenure and the rights associated with it.

Latin language.definition: Works relating to the vocabulary, use, grammatical rules, study or teaching of the Latin language, including grammars, dictionaries, vocabulary, rhetoric, style and composition etc.. Related keywords include ‘grammar’, ‘dictionary’, ‘rhetoric’, ‘art of writing’, and ‘Languages’.

Latude, J-H Masers de.definition: Famous inmate of the Bastille, imprisoned for denouncing an invented plot against Pompadour. Celebrated for his escape attempts.

Lauraguais.definition: French aristocrat and pamphleteer; associate of Louis XV. Also known as the Duc de Brancas.

Lausanne.definition: Can refer to either the town of Lausanne or its wider Canton.

Law.definition: Works relating to criminal, civil, ecclesiastical and international law, litigation, legal procedure and the legal profession.

Laws of Succession.definition: Works relating to the laws of inheritance and succession. This keyword incorporates both general legal treatises and works relating to specific cases, including legal briefs and judicial memoirs. A sub-category of ‘Law’ + ‘Inheritance’.

Leander, mythical figure.definition: Mythical Greek lover, drowned swimming Hellespont to meet his paramour Hero.

Legal codes.definition: Texts of law codes. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’.

Legal Codification.definition: Works relating to the history, theory and practice of codifying law. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’. NB. For texts of law codes the keyword ‘Legal Codes’ is used.

Legal profession.definition: Works relating to lawyers and their professional practices, organisation and training. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’.

Legal reform.definition: Works treating questions of large-scale reform in the laws, legal administration, procedures or penal codes of one or more states. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’.

Legislation.definition: Works concerning the principles or practice of creating / promulgating new laws. (As opposed to the text of ‘Law Codes’ or ‘Legislative measures’, both of which are separate keyword categories). This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’

Legislative measures.definition: Works announcing (usually newly) promulgated laws or edicts. (cf. ‘Legal codes’; ‘Legislation’). This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Law’.

Legitimacy of children.definition: Works relating to the legitimacy of children, whether on a general level or with regard to specific legal cases. See also works under the keyword ‘Illegitimacy’.

Lenclos, Anne de.definition: Celebrated seventeenth-century courtesan and early patron of Voltaire.

Lenoir, Jean-Charles-Pierre.definition: French minister of Police during the late ancien regime years.

lesbianism.definition: Works, usually literary, that depict, treat or discuss female same-sex sexual intimacy. Such works are usually erotic or pornographic in nature.

Libel and Slander.definition: Works treating libel and slander in general as their subject matter. NB. Libellous and scandalous attacks on individuals are listed under the keyword ‘Personal Libel’.

Libertine texts.definition: Texts (usually but not always novels) that reflect libertine sexual attitudes and behaviours. They may or may not be erotic or pornographic. The label is widely defined so as to include, for example, works depicting multiple ‘gallant intrigues.’ Qv. ‘Amorous adventures’.

Liege, Principality of.definition: Refers to the independent prince-bishopric of Liège in modern Belgium.

Linguet, Simon.definition: Celebrated French journalist and anti-philosophe. Executed during the revolution.

Linguistics.definition: Works concerned with the scientific study, especially comparative, of language and its structures. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Languages’.

List of officials.definition: ‘Official documents’ (such as Court Almanacs) listing the names and responsibilities of officials in a given state or states.

Literary Correspondence.definition: Collections of ‘Correspondence’ relating to the lives, works or opinions of leading literary figures and usually written by or to them. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Lives and Letters’ and ‘Correspondence’.

Literary Criticism.definition: Critical works treating creative literature. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Literary Studies’.

Literary History.definition: Works treating the history of literature. This keyword is a sub-category of ‘Literary Studies’.

Literary Prospectus.definition: This keyword is used to denote prospectuses for printed works other than serial publications.

Literary studies.definition: A generic category covering any work taking literature as its subject matter, whether ‘Literary history’, ‘Literary criticism’, or general literary reportage.

Literature.definition: Creative imaginative (fictional) written works of human spirit. [NB. The manes of Messrs Voltaire and d’Holbach should please note that this category does not include sacred texts or scriptures!]

Lives and letters.definition: Non-fiction works relating to the lives and / or correspondence of individuals.

Local politics.definition: Works concerned with the ‘Politics’ of a town or region within a larger state or entity.

Logic.definition: Works treating Logic. Such works are a sub-category of ‘Philosophy’.
